data.title: Index of Works
data.meta_description: In our gardens and parks, we strive for an atmosphere that makes it possible to sense the ancient longing for unity with nature.
data.text: That paradisiacal state in which people and animals lived in peace, in which nature was not the “evil other,” but was instead a harmonious part of the universe as a whole was once described as the Golden Age. Such a southern atmosphere, in which satyrs and fauns pursue nymphs by means of trickery and take their midday naps in the shade of reeds, guides us when designing and leads us to pictures that are determined by vegetation and seem timeless and serene. Whether in a park or on the side of a street, on public squares or in gardens: spatial qualities create locations that invite spending time. One senses a prankster behind one’s back—or is it a faun?
